text:
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES

WEDNESDAY, MARCH 21, 1883

THE OPPOSITION ORGAN.

As Dr. Porter has seen fit to announce that he will be present both in private and on the public platform, we do not hesitate to say that we shall be glad to see him in connection with the contest now going on for the representation of this district by the people.

Dr. Porter has stated on the public platform that we refused to publish anything handed to us by him. This statement is not true, and we feel sure that its falsity can be clearly proven. So far as that is concerned, this paper will not fail to do so.

We have always been willing to publish his grievances in his own person, but he refuses to come forward and make them known through the press.

The Prince Albert Times will therefore take no part in the discussion of this question.

THE REALIZATION.

Dr. Porter stated at the outset of the election that he had been compelled to offer himself as a candidate. In his letter published in THE TIMES at the time he said that he was requested to come out by a number of friends, and that he thought it best to accept the request.

If that request contains the name only of those friends who have not yet filled their canvassers' lists, then it is evident that he cannot have been asked to offer himself as a candidate. In his letter published in THE TIMES at the time he said that he was requested to come out by a number of friends, and that he thought it best to accept the request.

THE CAMPAIGN.

The Prince Albert Times has been obliged to give up its usual space for the publication of the speeches made by the candidates. It has been found impossible to get the speeches printed in time for publication.
